Tickets for the Hopkins-Maryland football game are now on
sale at the treasurer's office in
the basement of Remsen Hall. The
charge for student admissions will
be fifty cents with the presentation of an A. A. card. This is a
reduction from the price of last
year, which was one dollar.
Tickets for non-students are
for sale at one dollar each.

Second Issue Of'Blue Jay'
Out OnCampus Tomorrow
The unofficial magazine of the
Hopkins campus, the Blue Jay,
will be out today, according to
John G. Reddick, the editor.
This issue, which will be the
second, will contain stories, humor, campus news, fraternity
news, football, fashions, an action
picture of the St. John's game,
radio and band news.
Until last year, the Blue Jay
was called the Black and Blue
Jay, and was an official Hopkins
organ. Last year, however, student opinion did not warrant the
expense of continuing it as a part
of the University.

Southard Leads Field As
Team Scores In Annual
"Spiked Shoe" Event

Curtis High Second
City College Leads Local
Schools With 43 Points
To Capture Third Place
Defeating their nearest opponent
by seven points, Brooklyn Tech captured the third annual scholastic
cross-country run sponsored by the
Hopkins chapter of Spiked Shoe at
Homewood last Saturday.
Second in the point scoring was
Curtis High, the team that captured
the trophy last year. This school
provided the second and third-place
harriers in Simon and Peterson, but
Brooklyn Prep, with a better balanced aggregation and led by Southard, who was the individual winner,
was not to be denied the title.
Baltimore City College was third
with 49 markers, while Poly and Mt.
St. Joe trailed with 98 and 99 points,
respectively. This is the second year
in a row that visiting schools have
dominated the run, as Curtis and Mt.
Pleasant High School were first and
second in 1333. However, the local
schools, especially City College,
showed a great improvement over
preceding seasons, and furnished
hard competition for the leaders.
Race Close
The race was a particularly exciting one with the winner in doubt up
to the final stretch. Three runners,
Southard, Simon, and McElroy, Mt.
St. Joe ace, took an early lead and
held it for the first mile. At this point
McElroy, who had run himself out,
dropped back, and the run developed
into a duel between the two Metropolitans stars. The harriers went into
the final 440 even, but here Southard's
slightly superior stamina asserted itself, and he opened up a five-yard gap
which he continually increased, crossing the line 15 yards ahead.
An equally thrilling struggle was
waged over third position between
Martak, City College, and Peterson of
Curtis. Martak, who is only 13 years
old, and considered one of the finest
prospects in the state, led up to the
last 50 yards, when the Curtis runner made his bid and succeeded in
nosing out his competitor at the tape.
Other local harriers to perform well
were Brown, City College; McElroy,
Mt. St. Joe; and Chronister, City College. They finished 6th, 8th, and 9th,
respectively.

superior qualities.

year, which was one dollar.

for sale at one dollar each.

Second Issue Of'Blue Jay'
Out OnCampus Tomorrow
The unofficial magazine of the
Hopkins campus, the Blue Jay,
will be out today, according to
John G. Reddick, the editor.
This issue, which will be the
second, will contain stories, humor, campus news, fraternity
news, football, fashions, an action
picture of the St. John's game,
radio and band news.
Until last year, the Blue Jay
was called the Black and Blue

Southard Leads Field As
Team Scores In Annual
"Spiked Shoe" Event

Curtis High Second
City College Leads Local
Schools With 43 Points
To Capture Third Place
Defeating their nearest opponent
by seven points, Brooklyn Tech captured the third annual scholastic
cross-country run sponsored by the
Hopkins chapter of Spiked Shoe at
Homewood last Saturday.
Second in the point scoring was
Curtis High, the team that captured
the trophy last year. This school
provided the second and third-place
harriers in Simon and Peterson, but
Brooklyn Prep, with a better balanced aggregation and led by Southard, who was the individual winner,
was not to be denied the title.
Baltimore City College was third
with 49 markers, while Poly and Mt.
St. Joe trailed with 98 and 99 points,
respectively. This is the second year
in a row that visiting schools have
dominated the run, as Curtis and Mt.
Pleasant High School were first and
second in 1333. However, the local
schools, especially City College,
showed a great improvement over
preceding seasons, and furnished
hard competition for the leaders.
Race Close
The race was a particularly exciting one with the winner in doubt up
to the final stretch. Three runners,
Southard, Simon, and McElroy, Mt.
St. Joe ace, took an early lead and
held it for the first mile. At this point
McElroy, who had run himself out,
dropped back, and the run developed
into a duel between the two Metropolitans stars. The harriers went into
the final 440 even, but here Southard's
slightly superior stamina asserted itself, and he opened up a five-yard gap
which he continually increased, crossing the line 15 yards ahead.
An equally thrilling struggle was
waged over third position between
Martak, City College, and Peterson of
Curtis. Martak, who is only 13 years
old, and considered one of the finest
prospects in the state, led up to the
last 50 yards, when the Curtis runner made his bid and succeeded in
nosing out his competitor at the tape.
Other local harriers to perform well
were Brown, City College; McElroy,
Mt. St. Joe; and Chronister, City College. They finished 6th, 8th, and 9th,
respectively.

the grade of full professor be appointed for a limited term. Though the recommendation was not officially
adopted by the trustees, President
Ames is still of the opinion that the
positions of associate professor and
associate instructor should be limited
to five years so as to insure the injection of new blood in the faculty,
the balancing of the budget, and to
combat the possibility of dry rot.
